abstract.text: The goal of the KLOE-2 experiment operating at the upgraded DA NE e + e − collider is to collect an integrated luminosity of about 20 fb −1 over 3-4 years of running.
The KLOE-2 apparatus is now equipped with an inner tracker, new scintillation calorimeters and tagging detectors for γ γ physics.
These will allow measurements to refine and extend the KLOE programme on kaon physics and tests of fundamental symmetries as well as quantum interferometry.
Here the latest results from the KLOE data analysis are presented and the perspectives at KLOE-2 outlined.

body_text.text: Introduction

In the 2000-2006 data-taking period the KLOE detector, operating at the DA NE accelerator in the Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, acquired a total integrated luminosity of 2.5 fb −1 at the φ mass peak (corresponding to about 10 10 φ decays) and 250 pb −1 at √ s = 1 GeV (giving about 10 8 η mesons).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This allowed precise studies to be carried out on charged and neutral kaon physics, low energy QCD, as well as tests of CP and CPT conservation [1].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In 2008 the Accelerator Division of the Frascati Laboratory tested a new interaction scheme to allow the beam size to be reduced and the luminosity increased.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The test was successful and presently DA NE can reach a peak luminosity of 5 × 10 32 cm −2 s −1 , which is a factor of three better than previously obtained [2].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Following these achievements, the data-taking campaign using the upgraded KLOE detector on the improved machine will start in Autumn 2011.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The goal is to collect an integrated luminosity of about 20 fb −1 over 3-4 years of running.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The KLOE experiment at DA NE
DA NE is a e + e − collider operating near the φ meson mass peak, at a centre-of-mass energy √ s = 1019.45 MeV [1].
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: The heart of DA NE consists of two rings in which 120 bunches of electrons and positrons are stored.
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: Electrons are accelerated in the Linac, stored and cooled in the accumulator, and then transferred as a single bunch to the ring.
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: Positrons are first created at an intermediate station in the linac using 250 MeV electrons and then follow the same procedure as for electrons.
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: Electrons and positrons collide with small transverse momenta and produce φ mesons almost at rest (β φ ≈ 0.015).
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: The φ decay mainly into K + K − (49%), K S K L (34%), ρπ (15%) and ηγ (1.3%).
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: The decay products are registered using the KLOE detection setup.
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: This consists of a ≈ 3.3 m long cylindrical drift chamber, with a diameter of ≈ 4 m, which is surrounded by the electromagnetic calorimeter.
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: The detectors are placed in the axial magnetic field of a superconducting solenoid of strength B = 0.52 T. The KLOE drift chamber is constructed out of a carbon fibre composite with low-Z and low density and uses a gas mixture of helium (90%) and isobutane (10%).
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: It provides tracking in three dimensions, with a resolution in the transverse plane of about 200 μm, a resolution in the z-coordinate measurement of about 2 mm and 1 mm in the decay vertex position.
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: The momentum of a particle is determined from the curvature of its trajectory in the magnetic field with a fractional accuracy σ p / p = 0.4% for polar angles greater than 45 • [1].
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: The KLOE electromagnetic calorimeter consists of a barrel built out of 24 trapezoidally shaped modules and side detectors (so called endcaps) read out from both sides by a set of photomultipliers [1].
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: Each of the modules is constructed out of 1 mm scintillating fibres embedded in 0.5 mm lead foils to speed up the showering processes.
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: This detector allows measurements of particle energies and flight times with accuracies of σ E = 5.7%E/ √ E[GeV] and σ (t) = 57 ps/ √ E[GeV] ⊕ 140 ps, respectively.
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: Analysis of the signal amplitude distributions allows one to determine the place where the particle hit the calorimeter module with accuracy of about 1 cm in the plane transverse to the fibre direction.
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: The longitudinal coordinate precision is energy dependent:
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: . Since the φ mesons are produced almost at rest, kaons arising from the decay move at low speed with their relative angle being close to 180 • . As a consequence, the decay products are registered in well separated areas of the detector, which allows identification of K L mesons using reconstructed decays of K S (so called K L tagging) and vice versa. This is a special feature of the DA NE accelerator which, together with the KLOE detector, is a unique laboratory for kaon physics [3].
body_text.section: The KLOE experiment at DA NE

body_text.text: From KLOE to KLOE-2
In recent years, a new scheme for the machine based, on Crab-waist optics and a large Piwinsky angle [2], has been proposed to increase the DA NE luminosity.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: This has been tested successfully and it has motivated the start of a new KLOE run with an improved detector setup, named KLOE-2.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: This aims to complete the KLOE physics programme and perform a new set of interesting measurements [3].
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: For the forthcoming run we have improved the performance of KLOE by adding new sub-detector systems: the tagger system for γ γ physics studies, the Inner Tracker based on the Cylindrical GEM technology, a tile calorimeter surrounding the inner quadrupoles (QCALT), and a calorimeter between the interaction point (IP) and the first inner quadrupole (CCALT).
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: The tagging system is made up of two different detectors which are already installed and ready for data taking.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: The Low Energy Tagger (LET) is a small calorimeter placed inside KLOE near the IP, consisting of LYSO crystals read out by silicon photomultipliers.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: This sub-detector will serve to measure electrons and positrons from γ γ interactions within a wide energy range centred around 200 MeV with an accuracy σ E ∼ 10%.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: The second tagger, which is called the High Energy Tagger (HET), provides a measurement of the displacement of the scattered leptons with respect to the main orbit.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: This position detector consists of 30 small BC418 scintillators 3 × 3 × 5 mm 3 , which provide a spatial resolution of 2 mm (corresponding to a momentum resolution of ∼ 1 MeV/c).
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: The output light is collected by light guides with SiPM sensors.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: The HET allows measurements of particle energies with an accuracy of σ E ∼ 2.5 MeV and time with a resolution of σ t ∼ 200 ps.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: To improve the acceptance for low momentum tracks, and the vertex reconstruction near the interaction point, we are building the inner tracking chamber.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: This employs a novel technology with cylindrical GEM (Gas Electron Multiplier) detectors.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: It will be composed of four concentric layers that will provide 2-D points on a cylinder of known radius.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: Each layer is a triple-GEM chamber with cathode and anode made of thin polyamide foils.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: We will also install two additional calorimeters, named QCALT and CCALT.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: QCALT will be a 1 m long dodecagonal structure covering the region of the new quadrupoles.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: It is composed of a sampling of five layers of 5 mm thick scintillator plates alternated with 3.5 mm thick tungsten plates, for a total depth of 4.75 cm.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: The crystal calorimeter CCALT will cover the low polar angle region to increase the acceptance for very forward photons down to 8 • .
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: The basic layout consists of two small barrels of LYSO crystals that are read out with APD photosensors.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: A timing resolution between 300 and 500 ps is expected for 20 MeV photons.
body_text.section: From KLOE to KLOE-2

body_text.text: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

In addition to the preparation for the first KLOE-2 data-taking period (so-called Step0) and the activities for the design and construction of the new sub-detectors, there are still several ongoing physics analyses of the KLOE data.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: In kaon physics, apart from the recently published results of a precise K S lifetime measurement [4], there are several studies of neutral kaon interferometry and rare kaon decays, for example K S K L → π + π − π + π − interferometry or the K S → π 0 π 0 π 0 branching ratio measurement.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: These will be described briefly here.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: The decay of K S meson into three pions has not yet been observed, and the best limit on the branching ratio BR(K s → 3π 0 ) < 1.2 × 10 −7 [5] is about two orders of magnitude larger than predictions based on the Standard Model.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: Moreover, this process violates CP symmetry and, assuming CPT invariance, allows one to investigate direct CP violation.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: At KLOE this decay is reconstructed by searching for events with a K L interaction in the calorimeter (so called K L -crash), six photon clusters and no tracks from the interaction point.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: The background originates mainly from K S → 2π 0 events with two spurious clusters from splittings or accidental activity or is due to false K L -crash tags from φ → K S K L → π + π − π 0 π 0 π 0 events.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: In the latter case, charged pions from K S decays interact in the low-beta insertion quadrupoles, ultimately simulating the K L -crash signal, while K L decays close to the interaction point produce six photons [5].
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: To reduce the background, we first perform a kinematic fit with 11 constraints: energy and momentum conservation, the kaon mass and the velocities of the six photons.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: Cutting at a reasonable χ 2 value reduces considerably the background from false K L -crash events with little signal loss.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: In order to gain a good rejection of background from events with split or accidental clusters, we look at the correlation between the following two χ 2 -like discriminating variables, χ 2 3π and χ 2 2π .
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: χ 2 3π is the quadratic sum of the residuals between the nominal π 0 mass and the invariant masses of three photon pairs formed from the six clusters present.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: χ 2 2π is based instead on energy and momentum conservation in the φ → K S K L , K S → π 0 π 0 decay hypothesis, as well as on the invariant masses of two photon pairs.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: Both variables are evaluated with the most favorable cluster pairing in each case [5].
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: In addition, in order to improve the quality of the photon selection using χ 2 2π , we cut on the variable E = (m c 2 /2 − E γi )/σ E , where γ i is the i-th photon from the four chosen in the χ 2 2π estimator and σ E is the appropriate resolution.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: For K S → 2π 0 decays plus two background clusters, we expect E ∼ 0 while, for K S → 3π 0 , E ∼ m π 0 c 2 /σ E .
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: At the end of the analysis we cut also on the minimal distance between the photon clusters to refine the rejection of events with split clusters (see left panel of Fig. 1).
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: Applying the preliminary selection cuts, we find zero candidates in 1.7 fb −1 of real data with zero events expected from Monte Carlo, corresponding to an effective statistics of two times that of the data.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: This results in a new preliminary upper limit on the branching ratio BR(K S → 3π 0 ) < 2.9 × 10 −8 , which suggests that a first observation of the decay might be feasible at KLOE-2.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: A unique feature of the -factory is the production of neutral kaon pairs in a pure quantum state so that we can study quantum interference effects and tag pure monochromatic K S and K L beams.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: The decay rate of the system, for example, to the π + π − π + π − final state is proportional to:
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: where t is the time difference between the decays of the two kaons.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: If the neutral kaon system evolves in time as a pure quantum state, kaons cannot decay at the same time due to the destructive interference.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: But there are several potential mechanisms leading to decoherence of the state which may result from fundamental modifications of Quantum Mechanics or CPT violation induced, e.g.,by quantum gravity [3].
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: Thus, by measuring the t distribution, we can test the foundations of Quantum Mechanics as well as different phenomenological models of Quantum Gravity.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: At KLOE, the selection of a φ → K S K L → π + π − π + π − signal requires two vertices, each with two opposite-curvature tracks inside the drift chamber, with invariant mass and total momentum compatible with two neutral kaon decays.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: The resolution in t, the absolute value of the time difference of two π + π − decays, benefits from the precise momentum measurements and from the completeness of the kinematics of the events [6].
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: The experimental t distribution is fitted with (1), modified by parameters expressing decoherence in the different models described in [3].
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: The fit is performed taking into account the resolution and detection efficiency, the background from coherent and incoherent K S regeneration on the beam pipe wall, and the small contamination from the non-resonant e + e − → π + π − π + π − channel.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: The resulting distributions are shown together with the fit results in Fig. 1.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: On the basis of the 1.7 fb −1 of data, useful estimates could be made of several decoherence and CPT violating parameters.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: The details of the analysis and the results obtained can be found in [7].
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: It is worth mentioning that we have almost finished a refined analysis of the KLOE data with several improvements in the methodology.
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: Moreover, KLOE-2 with increased statistics (×4 in Step0) and improved resolution in the vertex reconstruction (×3 with the Inner Tracker) will be able to achieve the best experimental sensitivity in some observables, hopefully reaching the level of the Planck scale [3].
body_text.section: Recent KLOE results and the ongoing analysis in kaon physics

body_text.text: Summary
KLOE is a high precision experiment which allows detailed studies of both kaons and light scalar mesons, as well as tests of the conservation of CP, CPT and low energy QCD.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The success of the DA NE upgrade motivated a new experiment, KLOE-2, which aims at completing and extending the KLOE physics programme.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: We have started design and construction of new sub-detectors, which will improve the detection performance.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The tagging system for γ γ physics is installed and ready for the first phase of the experiment in which we expect to accumulate about 5 fb −1 .
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The next data-taking campaign during 2013-15 will be conducted with the Inner Tracker and improved photon acceptance brought about by the calorimeters in the final focusing region.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The total integrated luminosity expected in this second phase is about 20 fb −1 .
body_text.section: Summary
